page.title: 06Smarden - Ecology 2
page.content: Deciduous trees, especially oaks, do well here but wildlife has suffered from the removal of hedges by farmers, the cutting of verges by the council, the filling in of ponds and the use of pesticides and herbicides. Flowers such as orchids, Ragged Robin and poppies, once common, are almost gone. Apart from magpies and Canada geese, most bird species are declining, but foxes proliferate, as do rabbits along the railway, despite endemic myxomatosis. Mink are now a pest, living in ponds and rivers where they prey on fish and waterfowl. January 1985 was exceptionally cold, with icy east winds which killed even mature trees, brambles and gorse. Wild life is, however, cherished by many local people who encourage birds and animals in their gardens; bats, frogs, hares and owls all have their friends.
